column1: Before 5 August 2022, will Russia detonate a nuclear device outside of Russian territory or airspace?
column6: ['Technology', 'Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict']
Russia will not risk an escalation at this stage with US showing resolve to even tackle china on Taiwan
"...a single misunderstanding away from nuclear annihilation - so far we were lucky, but luck is not a strategy."

Down 2% for passage of time.
The risk is di minimis for the remaining time left before the question closes.

I still believe that nuclear escalation is inevitable assuming Putin stays in power. His only way out is through and Russia lacks the conventional force capabilities necessary to defeat Ukraine. This is a Russia vs the West war in Putin’s eyes. He will eventually escalate to WMD because it’s his only play.

Updating to zero from 1%. Seems to me that Russia's go-to strategy is a long bleed. Just yesterday, Russia announced decreasing Gazprom's output to Germany.

He will only do this as a last resort.

Dropping my forecast from 1% to 0%, due to having less than 3 weeks left on the question. I don't mean to say this is now impossible, only that I believe the odds of it in such a short time window are well under 0.5%, and that rounds to 0%.
If your prediction was 0% yesterday, you don't need to lodge another forecast to register a 0% today. It's already recorded at 0% today unless you change it.

Unless it is over the water as a threat. Unlikely to want to escalate. Losing game for Russia.
Russia has other levers to pull before it needs to pull this one.

“Within the next several months, we will transfer to Belarus the Iskander-M tactical missile systems, which are known to use both ballistic and cruise missiles, both conventional and nuclear,” Putin told Belarusian president Alexander Lukashenko in a meeting at St. Petersburg.

This recent article in The Atlantic outlines the current state of rhetoric regarding nuclear weapons use and the various scenarios: (1) a detonation over the Black Sea, causing no casualties but demonstrating Russian resolve to cross the nuclear threshold; (2) a decapitation strike against the Ukrainian leadership; (3) a nuclear assault on a Ukrainian military target that is not intended to harm civilians; and (4) the destruction of a Ukrainian city, causing mass civilian casualties and creating terror to precipitate a swift surrender

(no change and only slightly relevant) A fascinating article in "Atlantic" (no link) about US strategic strategy. One tidbit, a field grade officer at a war college did NOT know what MAD was. And some more about some in the chain of command or comparable civilians and Congress persons equally clueless.—oh my!
If it were to happen it would have happened 30 days ago. The triggering events have come and gone. Current estimate is 0.4% and rounding to 0.
Up 5%. Kaliningrad.
(no change) Fascinating history. Sam Nunn and William Perry are two of my heroes. Eric Schlosser is also a very thoughtful person.
Going nuclear would be a huge escalation for little gain tactical gain, apart from destroying a city. Whilst they may not be entirely rational I can't see it happening even 1 in 100 instances.

Reducing my forecast due to less time left on the question, and a general slowing of events in Russia / Ukraine somewhat. There are still risks, however.

The expansion of NATO is a clear sign for Russia not to escalate. Whether the Russians will understand it as such is another matter, but the transfer of the offensive towards the East shows a conventional war unfolding, which does not show significant escalation in rhethoric enough to justify a nuclear device, even in a false flag operation.

Update:Dropping this from 6% to 2%. Several reasons in past 48 hours:

Detonating a nuclear device outside of Russian territory would be a desperate act of last resort. I think the current administration has more rope to use before Aug 5, 2022. His mythology enjoys popular support both domestically and in neighboring countries. Until he's truly desperate, the cost of detonation outweighs the benefit.
On May 9th Russian Leadership will be at Parade. Ours will be sealed in the bunker complex. going up til the day after.
(no change) Russian losses related to Azovstal might cause some "what if" thinking among the Russian military.
Definitely non-zero, but I doubt Putin would make such an enormous, undeniable error - unless NATO troops were on the borders of Moscow, which I also do not see happening.
Staying steady at "non-zero" but close to it. The problem is Russian doesn't want to occupy irradiated land... (again.)

Significantly upgrading after reading about Russia's significant stock of small payloads. They wouldn't cause the devastation people would usually think about when they think nuclear weapons, but they would still meet the criteria of this question.
Dropping down 1% due to passage of time.

https://thebulletin.org/2022/04/will-putin-go-nuclear-a-timeline-of-expert-comments/ and https://thebulletin.org/2022/04/siegfried-hecker-putin-has-destroyed-the-world-nuclear-order-how-should-the-democracies-respond/#post-heading
Up 1%. "crazy (nixon) VP???"

It is hard for me to imagine the use of nuclear weapons on any actual group of humans, not because I consider Putin incapable but due to the number of things that would need to occur between point A and point B for it to happen. That is, once Putin were to order a strike, a large number of people would all have to take a series of specific actions to bring an actual detonation into being. Historically, when such orders have been given (since the advent of MAD), they have not been followed.
Going from 1% to 2% - it just seems a bit more likely in recent days. Still very unlikely in general, but Putin seems capable of using them.
Wouldn’t be a smart move, but I don’t trust Putin at all.
Given Putin's apparently deteriorating health.... he may want to show off before buggering off as a last performance act.

Russia keeps bringing up nuclear war. It is almost certainly a bluff. But they may think they need to make a demonstration to back up future bluffs. I'm not sure whether it would lead to a Tit-for-Tat exchange. Perhaps Russia is not sure either and will become desperate enough to believe they need to prove their nukes work and that they are willing to use them regardless of what they think might be a low risk of reprisal.

Going back up to one. Vlad the Shirtless is increasingly desperate, and one does not like to contemplate what measures he might pursue when the shirt hits the fan. There is always some hope that his surviving command-level guys will either talk him out of something like this, or drag their feet indefinitely in ersatz compiance with his orders.
Game theory has prevented this from happening for decades. Why now?

The more desperate Putin becomes he will continue to escalate to de-escalate. In 1999 while serving on the Security Council of the Russian Federation Putin implemented his escalation management style; escalate to de-escalate projection of power in response to the West’s approach of calculated ambiguity which probably stokes paranoia. He has an existential imperative to stay in power by all means. If Putin sees that he will lose the war, he will use anything to project power. If he doesn’t it’s over for him and it will end very badly. It is a matter of survival for him.

Russia has never detonated a nuclear device outside of Russian territory except as a test, and all those sites are former USSR but now independent states, making it highly unlikely they'd agree to a test detonation. Further Russia has abided by the test ban treaty since 1990. I don't consider a nuclear war to be likely as Ukraine is not a NATO state and I have serious doubts a NATO state would wish to be the first to use nuclear weapons. Unless NATO fires first, I doubt Russia will initiate a nuclear conflict as the threat level will not be high enough. Even if a conventional war with NATO breaks out, Russia has retained its professional non-conscript forces and advanced weapons (e.g. T-90 tanks) and has not deployed these in Ukraine, giving it a strong defensive screen. Russia has hypersonic missiles which it has demonstrated to be accurate and has just demonstrated a hypersonic kinetic energy ICBM as a deterrent to NATO.
@Alosto below made a very good point. I’m adjusting to 0%, but I just wonder if they do know that detail. After all their pride ship “Moskva” was sunken by a country that doesn't have a Navy!!
Adjusted for passed time.
Though the event itself is plausible, the time-frame is so short that I believe the probability is sub-1 percent. Their last nuclear test was in 1990, while still under the Soviet Union.
It is a hideous scenario

With current pressures from NATO and economic struggles currently faced in Russia, I find it highly unlikely that they would go to such drastic measures as to release a nuclear bomb over Ukraine or any other nation (especially since they seem to wish to occupy Ukraine, not demolish it). The detonation of a nuclear weapon outside of Russian airspace would most likely result in the hostile retaliation of NATO among dozens of other countries who participated in The Treaty on the Prohibition of Nuclear Weapons.

A step too far. I cannot assess what US and Europe would do other than the current approach is "to not provoke Putin" so the concept of Mutually Assured Destruction is not being tested in public. BUT Putin may be desperate but not suicidal - he is using brinksmanship in public but i suspect we are more deliberate behind closed doors.

I'd love to go to zero, but can't say it is impossible. I've stayed at 1% for a while... and the only thing that'll bring me/us lower is the passage of time. That said, it is affirming that US Intelligence agrees:
Everything the Kremlin comes out with seems to be false, so this worries statement me: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-04-19/russia-will-not-use-nuclear-weapons-in-ukraine-lavrov-says

I am watching France 24 right now. The Debate. Consensus he is bluffing. Consensus we should bluff in response.i agree. Failure to respond encourages further threats. Indeed it appears Biden NATO approach is to allow such threats to deter West from providing Ukraine with weapons to win so we suppky just enough to stalemate Russia. We seem to be afraid Ukraine will actually win because this will force Putin into a corner and we are afraid what Putin will do. Wrong. This is a fight to the finish and will be decided on battlefield. Do we want UKraine to win. Absolutely. Can the West afford for Ukraine to lose. No. This is like Battle of Marathon 490 b.c. This is a battle for Western civilization against an oriental despot. Dare to win.

Russian media and politicians have become increasingly apocalyptic in their discussion of Putin's War, and dehumanising towards Ukrainians. Russia has performed very poorly on the battlefield, necessitating new tactics. It has struggled to knock out any major urban centres or infrastructure, whereas a nuclear strike would be relatively effective. It has demonstrated extreme brutality towards Ukrainians in occupied areas and a disdain for human life. Putin likes to escalate when things aren't going his way. He may fear for his life if the war grinds on without a quick resolution in the next 4-6 weeks, as the risk of mutinies and mass protests rises. All of these factors strongly militate towards his use of nuclear weapons against the Ukrainians.

The crowd is already at only 1%, so I'm not sure how much value my forecast offers here, but I will point out that the US in Vietnam studied the idea of using tactical nuclear weapons (TNWs) in that conflict and firmly rejected the idea, concluding that it would be counterproductive, for the following reasons:
I think the harder winning the war with conventional weapons is for Russia, the greater the odds they use tactical nukes.

Despite making a statement that an existential threat to their own land is considered, or weapons aid to Ukraine, it is still not entirely clear what the scale of this sensitive line actually is. But I don't think it will be aimed at Ukraine in this direction. And, the goal is not to turn that place into hell, but to reach the goal on a small and large scale. İt seems, considering for a major war Russia cannot win a war without nuclear weapons. Revolving and limiting himself by the possibilities he put forward for himself at now.

The Russian offensive seems to have stalled, additional peace talks are under way, and a recent announcement by Kremlin spokesperson states that "any outcome of the operation [in Ukraine] is not is not a reason for usage of a nuclear weapon". https://www.newsweek.com/russia-ukraine-peskov-putin-nuclear-weapons-biden-1692753 while the track record of Russians announcing one thing and doing the opposite recently goes against this forecast, nuclear war is a domain which is almost guaranteed to bring about a response from NATO, and as such could be considered an exception.

Reconsidering after reading the Economist's convincing coverage of the implications of Kahn's and others theoretical thinking on the issue (https://www.economist.com/briefing/2022/03/19/the-risk-of-escalation-past-the-nuclear-threshold; https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2022/03/19/the-disturbing-new-relevance-of-theories-of-nuclear-deterrence). I'm still convinced that the probability of nukes entering the game is very small, hence my estimate is still below 5%. But it can't be excluded and I'm indeed becoming more and more convinced that it hasn't been as likely as now that nukes could be used for the past six decades.

(no change) I wish 46 had stuck to "there is a war crimes process" line. There can't be too much caution right now.

Concepts of MAD still hold. I believe that Putin was leveraging "escalate to deescalate" doctrine when he changed the Russian nuclear alert level. The war on Ukraine is in very, very early days in terms of how long it could last, given that while Russia has experienced serious issues with maintenance and logistics, the simple fact is that they have a much larger pool of military resources & soldiers than Ukraine. I could only find data on civil wars, but the length of those conflicts has lasted between 7-10 years in the 21st century and one could easily expect ongoing insurgency in Ukraine.
VP is backing down and setting up others to take the fall. EU leaders entering Ukraine. Negotiations continuing.

Raising this to 5% from 3%. Reports have indicated NBC suits have been shipped to troops in Ukraine. As I had earlier considered a thermobaric weapon to be a precursor escalation to using tactical nukes, I must now also consider Chemical weapons to also be a precursor weapon. There is now confirmed capture of thermobaric launchers by the UF.
This is a bleak question, but cannot be ruled out. Masha Gessen predicted this could happen at a Polish AFB to test the waters…

As Russia continues to be slowed in its advance in Ukraine by inept conscript troops and Ukrainian forces, it is increasingly likely to use a tactical nuclear weapon to gain an advantage that wasn't possible in purely conventional warfare. The use of nuclear weapons in this instance is consistent with Russian doctrine. It may also serve as a deterrent to US/NATO countries to not intervene to avoid escalation. However, this likelihood will decrease if Russia can make significant tactical gains over the next 10 days while it still maintains some momentum and before logistics resupply is necessary.
I actually think there's a meaningful chance a test shot is fired, perhaps over the Black Sea. But, it still remains very unlikely this will happen outside of Russia

They wan to make this territory unlivable and useless so even abandoned it would be no gain no advantage to Nato.

The utilization of WMDs by Russian in any form increases as their objectives are not met militarily as does their sense of escalation by Western actors.
Lowering … Russia’s response to oil sanctions was their own sanctions.

Movement of Russian nuclear forces to combat mode so a nuclear launch order could go through, increases the chance. Considering both strategic and tactical nuclear devices. Stop at the Ukraine, if that is the objective? Or continue on West?
Hard to believe they would.
Russians don't want a nuclear war anymore than anyone else does! Putin is somewhat calculating.
Getting more risky.

Except for miscalculation or accident, I don't see it as very likely. edit: But maybe the only thing preventing this is a hybrid war created with cyber and sanctions in this way. Or different kinds of mobility. So I no longer think that this principle of cause and effect works in the opposite way as a whole.

If past is prologue, the likelihood of such an event is very low at best. The Cold War provided for several crises that could had escalated into nuclear war, but didn't because of the catastrophic ramifications. But unlike the Cold War, where the Party and generals held sway with leaders in the USSR, Russia does not currently enjoy that luxury. Aside from North Korea, no other country in the nuclear world is almost unilaterally controlled by the psychi of one man, Vladimir Putin. He is now the character in his childhood nightmare; the cornered rat. Putin's only way out is through; there is no going back. One key indicator is the rapid pace of escalation in Ukraine. Only days into the invasion, Putin quickly escalated the conflict by indiscriminate bombing of civilian targets. He's adaptied to the reality of a weaker-than-anticipated conventional force capability. The information war against NATO is full of absurd lies and propaganda and bellicose threats of nuclear (non-conventional) war on a scale never seen. These are telegraphed punches, not hollow deterrent threats. Russian nuclear doctrine provides for limited first use of nuclear weapons and those responsible for carrying out such orders are streamlined and will be carried out. Much like climate change, Putin is not deterred by the potential catastrophic consequences. He believes he is a savior and his demonstration of unrestrained brut force will likely deter the West from responding in kind and move the crisis towards deescalation. Even if the West does respond, Putin see himself as surviver, the rat. The US and NATO are frail bunnies. Rats will survive a nuclear war, bunnies will not.

Taking the probabilities from the catastrophic risk survey, there is 10% chance of >1 billion dead before 2100 and 1% of extinction. So chance of any nuclear blast is ~30%? Then the chance of it happening from my precursory understanding is during a crisis like the one we see now where there is most likely a mistake (e.g. Russian systems incorrectly showing incoming missiles from the U.S.). So how often do crisis such as this occur? Maybe since that survey in 2008 once before with N.Korea and now. So maybe 5 more before 2100? Then saying 20% of the 30% risk is during crisis like now, distributed over these 7 events puts it at 3%? I guess somewhere between 1%-10% chance of at least one nuclear missile being launched and detonating. Take this with a grain of salt, ideally with iodine!

+1 Lavrov, in his press conference in Italy just now is saying that Russia does not want a nuclear war, but that NATO is obsessed with nuclear war. He is setting up a situation were if Russia detonated a nuclear device, it would be defensive or reactionary rather than offensive. This is consistent with his position that the attack on Ukraine was purely defensive and Russia had no other choice given the threat.

The baseline or nuclear detonations outside of Russian (and its predecessor country the Soviet Union) is zero, even if some of the testing took place outside the current Russian territory. The baseline for nuclear weapons to be used in a conflict is 0,025 (2/78 years since the WW2 bombings). The extensive work against proliferation makes it very unlikely. While Putin has an ongoing conflict in Ukraine it has other avenues of pressure on NATO and Ukraine, by potentially provoking a nuclear incident (shelling of Zaporizhzhia power plant, which sparked Ukrainian fears of an intentional nuclear crisis, disconnection of the Chernobyl plant from monitoring and power supply)
Putin is Putin.

a launch of a nuclear device to the sea would show off their power and deter, with only a break of the non-nuclear proliferations treaty and even more international condemnation. probability would change if they used other methods of deterrence, if they become/appear successful in ukraine's takeover, or successfully cut of nato's supply lines.
May be tactical, with enough intelligence and desperation; to launch a nuclear device to cut off nato. international condemnation would not matter

We are in uncharted waters, Russia invading West rather than the West invading East...Putin states his objective, to reconstitute the Soviet Union - but is that his limit? I doubt Putin knows how far he may go - it's clear he is testing the West, along with China & India too, and plenty of accounts indicate the man isn't well. Looks to me that he is recreating what happened in Leningrad, where his elder brother starved to death due to the 2 yr plus siege. I believe his mind may now be broken, but that members of his entourage are partly rational - setting objectives (reconstitute USSR, commence with Ukraine), - measuring action (is it working?) - taking evasive action (escalation is an expensive option). If we follow the money, it's hard to see the nuclear option enabling Russia to enter what could be left of the global economy. I say 2%, 1% for intent, and another for an accident
Putin is a madman who will not admit defeat.
If either Putin is rational or the other links in the chain are both rational and brave, then there will be no use of nuclear weapons by Russia.
US Space Force has come out with a promotional announcing a schedule to extend its patrols into space and the Moon by 2035/
I think about accidental vs. intentional. The former is a di minimus risk. The latter requires and order by VP. The question is will it be carried out? Maybe not.

Mr. Putin may have a death wish, but it is unlikely that those closest to him share it. The odds of an accidental detonation, which is theoretically possible, are unlikely given the security protocols. The most likely scenario involving nuclear capabilities outside Russian territory or airspace could be bombing a nuclear power plant within Ukraine, due to Russian forces' lack of regard/training and/or poor judgment to shell nuclear facilities. This would not meet the criteria for the question as I interpret it.
https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-60683248

There is substantial probability that Russia does not take over Kyiv or other crucial Ukrainian cities by August 2022. Depending on inner political pressure and his mental state, Putin might feel the need to risk a high gamble to reduce some of the imposed sanctions or NATO military aid. He could do this by dropping a nuclear bomb in a sparsely populated area or airspace to assure the NATO of the seriousness of his threats and at the same time not provoke a direct counterattack (which, of course, could still happen).

This is actually a huge swing from the baseline at almost all times of 0.00. It reflects a shift from "not just no, but hell no," to "it seems really unlikely but it's possible." What makes it so is that there are now a couple of scenarios where Russian nuclear use could result from deliberate choice (if Ukrainains appear to be winning) or escalations if the Russians tried to interdict supply lines come from Poland or other NATO countries. This forecast question does point to the scoring challenge of rare events.

If the Russians continue to struggle against the Ukrainians, the use of tactical nuclear weapons becomes increasingly likely. Tactical nuclear weapons have a 30 to 200 kiloton yield meant to be used on the battlefield, not for the destruction of a city (however, of note, the only nuclear bombs to ever be dropped on a city were 13 kiloton. Most modern nuclear bombs are between 475 kilotons to 1.4 megatons). The United States no longer has a useable supply of tactical nuclear weapons, whereas the Russians have a large stockpile. During the Cold War the possible use of tactical nuclear weapons was viewed as a strategic advantage for the Russians as there was no proportional response for the West. If Putin is determined to subdue the Ukrainians, tactical nuclear weapons are a real possibility.

My probability estimate is not acutally zero, but they are so close to zero that it makes sense from my point of view to stay below the crowd estimate. There is always the probability of an accident or misunderstanding. However, the base rate for this seems quite small. Despite many close calls in the past 70+ years, no such instance has occurred. I also wouldn't categorially exclude the possibilty that tactical nukes are an option for Russia to win the war against Ukraine. But the probability seems very low for this as the risks of escalation of this conflict by deploying even a small nuke seem very high.

1. The longer it takes to crush Ukraine, the higher the chances of using a tactical nuke 2. The more the West supports Ukraine, the higher the chances the Russians will pop a nuke over an ocean to say 'back off' as pre planned in doctrine. 3. If the Russians get bogged down, they will detonate a vacuum bomb before a nuke. So odds of a nuke go up after a vac bomb is popped. https://www.defenseone.com/threats/2022/03/concern-rising-putin-could-use-nuclear-weapons/362913/

Putin's final goal is not to destroy the world. Rather, he wants to expand Russia's sphere of influence, reduce perceived external threats, and cement his place in history. Thus there is a di minimus risk of a catastrophic nuclear attack. Russia has plenty of conventional military strength yet untapped in the current war against Ukraine. Therefore, any use of nuclear weapons will be limited to tactical, rather than strategic use. However, the cases where I think Russia may detonate a nuclear device outside of Russia are, 1) If losing badly in Ukraine or broader war involving NATO and a demonstration effect needs to take place to turn the tide (i.e., use a tactical weapon to demonstrate a willingness to do more if the other side doesn't give in), 2) If NATO and Russia end of in a military conflict and NATO takes the fight deep in inside Russia (e.g. St. Petersburg, Moscow, or other key cities), 3) if economic warfare against Russia reaches consequences that are unacceptable to Russia and there is no other way to stop them (again as a demo effect that more will follow). Base rate of usage is very low, but not that meaningful here. All worse case scenarios may easily NOT happen by August 5, as Russia has many options to stay afloat economically and the ground war in Ukraine can easily continue until August. I expect the conventional war to continue for a long time.
Too many eager beavers leaning in. Save me from do-gooders! Who the H_ _ _ thought that VP might just shrug off transferring MiGs??

I hope not! But he can lose his patience as the was has not progressed as expected. He may not detonate a nuclear device but he has currently taken nuclear plants from Ukraine which in some way he would not be violating any of the nuclear agreements if he decides using them as massive weapons.
Going up briefly.

If Putin's war deteriorates and he is unable to keep making progress, he is likely to keep escalating as he has done in Syria and Chechnia before, Nuclear is unlikely as they are making sufficient progress to avoid nuclear escalation if the Russian army keeps being bogged down in Ukraine, and economic and popular pressure increases he may be seeking a quick vicotry.

This is almost entirely a prediction based on the possibility of Putin deploying a small yield battlefield (or tactical) nuke on Ukrainian soil. At a very high level, in terms of forecasting the Russia-Ukraine crisis, some of the errors made by Superforecasters in their post-mortem of predicting an invasion (thanks to @ctsats , http://goodjudgment.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/1570-Post-Mortem.pdf) was overemphasizing base rates like war in Europe, and underestimating Putin's willingness to take major risks. Its hard not to see those same types of errors applying to this type of question, meaning a near-zero crowd forecast is almost certainly not correct.

The detonation of a nuclear device by Russia outside of Russia would obliterate the fiction that Putin is trying to sell the Russian people about why Russia is engaged in a 'special military operation' - but not a 'war' - in the eastern Ukraine and imperil Putin's political survival domestically. The international response to a nuclear detonation might start measured, but it's hard to envision circumstances where NATO forces wouldn't get killed, so this would certainly draw a reciprocal response. Russia isn't irrational: no advantage to be gained, then exceedingly unlikely to try this course.

Escalation would have to start on the Russian side, so it's critical that the US, NATO, non-aligned nations, and Ukraine not give Putin the impression that Russian territorial integrity is threatened. If so, the risks of nuclear exchange go up significantly. As for Putin's personal integrity (his own death), I believe he would flee with a few billion before being deposed or killed, and not resort to pressing the button before leaving, although it's a possibility that leads me to my 1% forecast. Nuclear weapons are the ultimate weapons to have, but counterintuitively they are more useful when they are not deployed. Let's consider the past trends in nuclear weapons' use for military purposes (not testing): here we are basically talking about Hiroshima and Nagasaki, two catastrophic events unfortunately "legitimised" in the framework of an all-out war and in a period in which the US were not limited by anyone's possible counter-strike with the same weaponry. Before even considering the nukes' deployment, the state of the war would need to be much, much farther beyond repair. I put a conservative 1% possibility and not a round 0% only because I acknowledge my possible failure in immagination and the very unlikely possibility of such a deterioration of the war's status (and the utter failure of any diplomatic solution) in such a relatively short amount of time.

Going above the crowd on this one to begin with. Its an unlikely outcome, but tensions are high and there are many ways this could happen: - use of a small/tactical nuclear weapon against forces perceived to threaten Russia (at the moment there are none). - use of a nuclear weapon as a demonstration/threat to NATO (perhaps over sea or at very high altitude; still very harmful). - use of a nuclear weapon as retaliation to a non-nuclear action (insane, but so is invading Ukraine). - accidental detonation of a nuclear weapon (more likely to occur inside Russia though). - use of a nuclear weapon in response to false and/or incomplete information (especially if tensions rise higher).
